definition[0]: if a car or machine breaks down, it stops working
example[0]: The car broke down just north of Paris.
example[1]: The printing machines are always breaking down.
definition[1]: to fail or stop working in a successful way
example[2]: Negotiations broke down after only two days.
example[3]: I left London when my marriage broke down.
definition[2]: if you break down a door, you hit it so hard that it breaks and falls to the ground
example[4]: Police had to break down the door to get into the flat.
definition[3]: to change or remove something that prevents people from working together and having a successful relationship with each other
example[5]: Getting young people together will help to break down the barriers between them.
example[6]: It takes a long time to break down prejudices.
definition[4]: if a substance breaks down, or something breaks it down, it changes as a result of a chemical process
example[7]: Food is broken down in the stomach.
example[8]: Bacteria are added to help break down the sewage.
definition[5]: to be unable to stop yourself crying, especially in public
example[10]: She broke down in tears when she heard the news.
definition[6]: to separate something into smaller parts so that it is easier to do or understand
example[11]: He showed us the whole dance, then broke it down so that we could learn it more easily.
example[12]: The question can be broken down into two parts.
definition[7]: to separate information or a total amount into parts, especially so that it is easier to understand
example[13]: Once the statistics are broken down, some clear patterns of employment begin to emerge.
definition[8]: if talks break down, they fail and come to an end because the people involved cannot agree
example[14]: The meeting between management and unions broke down and no progress was made.
